monogr.title: A translation of the booke of nature, into the vse of grace : Performed and principally intended for the benefit of those who plead ignorance, or they are not book-learned, or that they want teachers and so thinke to excuse themselues in their sinnes. By William Evans, Mr of Arts of St Mary Hall in Oxford
monogr.author: Evans, William

div.p:

And hauing tried all the waies and baits, and meanes that I could thinke of, and were allowable for me to vse for that purpose, At last I found that saying to be true,
Segnius irritant animos, demissa per aures,
Quam quae sunt oculis subiecta fidelibus. Horat. Art. Poet
That ignorant people are sooner perswaded by plaine similitudes and familiar examples, then with subtill reasons, and accurate discourses: And finding it so, I fell, and set vpon this worke, which I call, A Translation of the Booke of Nature into the vse of Grace. And here least any man should thinke, that in thus doing, I attribute too much to Naturall reason and Philosophie; as if the points of Religion might be sufficiently proued, and demonstrated thereby; I shall desire you to doe me that favour, as first to heare what I say; and see what I doe, and then Iudge. For Philosophie, I neither altogether seclude her out of the Church, as some would doe; neither would I willingly suffer her to advance her selfe aboue Divinity, Naturalistae. as others would haue. I reverence Divinity, as the Mistres, I respect Philosophy, as the Hand-maide to this Mistres. Moses, and the Prophets, and the Apostles, Men of vnquestionable iudgement haue done so: And so I haue ranked them in this Treatise, giving Divinity the priority, to speake in every thinge; and then Philosophy the next place, to speake and to illustrate the matter. If I had let naturall reason, and Philosophy, speake in these things alone, then thou mightest iustly except against me,
Aquinas 1 part. quaest. 1. art. 10. and say with the Schooleman, Theologia symbolica non est per se argumentatiua: Or if I had let reason and Philosophy speake in the first place, I might likewise haue beene iustly blameable, for as the Schoolemen say well, Rationes praecedentes minuunt fidem, reasons going before faith, weaken faith: But inasmuch as I haue made Reason to speake, and to serue in the second place, & like a Handmaide,
to haue alwayes her eyes toward her Mistres Divinity, howsoeuer thou iudgest of it, certainely the Schoolemen will say, Rationes subsequentes augent fidem, that reasons comming after faith, doe strengthen faith. Reason makes not the matter more sure, ex parte veritatis dictantis, in respect of God the speaker: but ex parte intellectus assentientis, in respect of the weakenesse of our vnderstanding, which by the acesse of farther knowledge is more confirmed. But these things happly allowed, here againe it may be farther said, that I am too Copious, and frequent in this kinde of argument: or else having set vpon it, that my Translation is not so full, and perfect, as it should be. For the first, my frequencie in this kinde of teaching, the Hebrew verily shall speake for me, wherein as the learned obserue, almost every word hath a Metaphoricall sense, and doth illustrate by some allusion: imo Haebrei quodvis sapienter & subobscurè dictum maximè quod est de hominis siue naturâ, siue officio,

Maschal id est similitudinem appellant, hoc enim sensu Dicta Salomonis Ethica, quae Proverbia vulgò appellamus, Piscat. in Mat. c. 15.S. nominantur

Mischlé shelomó, id est, parabolae Salomonis. And for the second, I humbly acknowledge it, but yet that shall not deterre me from my intended purpose; Malim enim aliquid agendo, majorem à me doctrinam, & sapientiam desiderari, quàm nihil agendo, prudentior, doctiòr{que} judicari: having receiued a talent from the Lord, I know my selfe bound, and that by a straight charge, to negotiate therewith, Luk. 19.13. Mat. 25.27. and to put it to the vttermost profit, I had rather then, by doing some good, lay open my infirmities to the censures of men; then by idlenesse, to hide my talent in the earth, and so to incurre the indignation of my Lord. Besides if I had prosecuted this argument at this time euer so farre, and euer so exactly, yet I know I should not (no more then my betters) escape the lash of censure, especially of deficient minds, and such as knowe, or doe least, whose property is, to seeke by censuring, to be accounted wise, and to get themselues grace by disgracing of others.

But howeuer whether by grace or disgrace, or to vse the words
of the Apostle, 2. Cor. 6. v. 8. Whether by honour or dishonour, euill report or good report, thus farre I am contented at this time, to trauell abroad for the common good: And in speciall for your good, Gal. 4.19. little Children, of whome I travell in birth, till Christ be formed in you: If I find that this my travell likes you, and that any good comes of it, I shall be ready to goe on farther for you in this kinde: In the meane space desiring your acceptance, in way of recompence, I commend you to God, and to the word of his grace, and rest

closer.signed: Yours, according to my Talent, both to Preach, and to pray for you. WILLIAM EVANS.
